translations.translation: I killed an emu the day before yesterday.
I killed an emu long ago.
Often I used to kill emus.
I used to eat meat not often.
You often (habitually) eat (much) meat.
Eat that meat.

notes: subject pronoun present with IMP, but unlike other sentences such as 'Eat food here', it comes before the verb
note object also comes before both subject and verb

translations.translation: I give it to you.

sentences.transcription: ngathu nguthianha yurranha ngutyagala/ yurrangu dhalhtharra

translations.translation: I give meat to you to eat.
O.K., I am finished.
The two of you will give me much meat.
I am without meat.
This dog is good.
This dog is good.

notes: alternative word order (dog this good) for previous sentence (this dog good)

translations.translation: That dog (far away) is good.

notes: Good example of nominative cases too

translations.translation: Two dogs.
Two men are coming together.

notes: number agreement within the noun phrase
gloss for dhika is 'go back' but translation is 'coming together' - deixis?

translations.translation: The two of them (are coming) this way.
A mob is coming.

notes: implies that the gloss of -dhika isn't right?

translations.translation: Many people are hitting each other.
What for?
A man there stole another man's wife.
He hit himself with a stone axe.
I hit myself.

notes: example - simple sentence for reflexive pronoun

translations.translation: I saw a possum up there.
I see you.
I see him.

sentences.transcription: walya ngathu inha nadyagala/ yurru walbirrianha

translations.translation: I don't see you - only your shadow.

notes: example - first part could be a simple example for negation

translations.translation: Come on, the two of us sit in the shade.
The sun is shining hot.
Whose is this dog running around?
My father's dog is running around.
Chase that dog away.

notes: Difference between zero inflection for imperative and -dhika?
re: above note, it seems that -dhika always adds the meaning of 'back/away' when used with zero imperatives. It's glossed as 'go back' in other places as a verb

translations.translation: It could bite that kid.

sentences.transcription: manhdhawarri yandraanha nhanhaguru/ barnrdidhikarra nhanhaguru dhithianha

translations.translation: Pick up a stone, hit him away, that dog.
Uncle is making a boomerang.
My uncle is making a boomerang.
Uncle is making it for me. OR Uncle is making the boomerang. It is for me. OR Uncle is making (it). The boomerang is for me.
This is not your boomerang.
That boomerang is my father's.
Whose is that spear lying in the grass there?
Whose is that?

notes: is this really nominative? Looks like a pronoun here.

translations.translation: Pick up that spear. (It) might break.
Lean it standing up.

notes: IMP -rra here is not attaching to a verb -- yes it is, dhina(ba) is a verb meaning 'stand'

translations.translation: Yes, (I) pick that one up.
Put it up there in the shade.
His father is going away.
Who picked up my stick here?
I couldn't/didn't find my stick.
I picked it up and threw it in the fire.
Finished, burnt that one down there in the fire.
I'll pick up a stick, that one/for you.
Come away, the dog could bite you.
That one down there is playing with the good dog.
The dog is fighting the kangaroo.

sentences.transcription: walya wina yanhthadhira/ galkalangu inha nhandruguru dhaldraandru

translations.translation: Don't go too close, the kangaroo could kill you.
Don't go too close, the two of us will kill it with a spear.
Stand back.

notes: not sure if this is 'foot' here or -dhika derives a verb.

translations.translation: I didn't hit it.
(Give) me a stick.
Finished/O.K., I killed it.
Call your dog off.
That one is tearing up the meat.

sentences.transcription: nalyba nganha ngutya gakagakarra nguthianha nhanha

translations.translation: Give me a knife to cut up the meat there.

sentences.transcription: nhanha ngathu durrkaanha waltagala nganytya gawulidyaanga ngurraanga ngutyarra ngathu nhanha nguthianha

translations.translation: I am taking this leg to my uncle's camp to give him the meat.
